entry.def: misty patches of drizzle, weather condition.
contract sum of money in deposit.
wrist band of a wrist watch.
the eye of the winder through which the thread runs in the course of spinning.
teeth of the winder in the spinning wheel.
not much as: Cha d’fhuair e sian.
packing between the edges of a blank [plank?] in a boat.
(also) a baby’s handful, or a child’s handful.
little bits. Thug e dhà e ’na chiobhanan.
planting potatoes by making holes in the ground and dropping the cumber [?] in; a person employed likewise.
(also) thread binder in a spinning wheel.
groan, life [?] càil ach gu bheil an rong ann.
a portion of material or meat being pulled to a fair size. Slaoic dhe neo dhi.
a small stone on which to lay a burden from the shoulders for a bit of rest.
a stone thrown into a small bog or puddle to prevent a person getting stuck in the mud.
a boundary by a croft with an unauthorative [sic] claimant or possessor.
forcing. Na bi dha storadh oirre.
lap. Thoir leat ’n a do sgùirt e.
bare feet. An robh thu air do spòg-ris?
an old version of potato ‘measurement’ or container.
barrel for storing fresh water, etc.
treacle cask from which treacle was released for consumption.
treacle from small barrels. An old form of expression, perhaps the same kind of treacle from different containers.
the sugar before being finally granulated.
(also) a small point. Gobag sear – place-name Scalpay (East small point).
“ready to tell wee female”. ’S e cabag a th’annad.
(also) term used for describing a ‘sharp faced’ or a pointed appearance of a female. (Variation of meaning from the one word.)
sculling form of movement with liquid.
the pale brown back, flies on a cow pat.
perhaps I have noted this word formerly, it’s a swear word I think?
fan, propellent [sic] form of instrument for fanning in warm weather.

if you haven’t any word or meaning for this term, with which I am not certain, perhaps you will take it as ‘roots of Rhubarb and Docken’. There is Sealbhag, but I heard this term also used (old form?). I haven’t consulted documents, it was a word I once heard years back.
dasher, a lively person dashing from one place to another in the person of a travelling agent, or ‘ceannaiche siubhail’. (One version.) Tómas dusheir – word signifying his trade and movement.
perhaps I have noted this one already: it doesn’t matter anyway. Sgin [sic]; derived from sgian, skin etc. Sginnidh mi thu.
‘blanket’. ’S e plangaid de dhuine th’ann – clumsy, as a person moving with a blanket around him etc.
[See plangaid.] In the form of describing a human characteristic movement, as: Plaite de dhuine – a bedcover of a man or a man covered trying to move etc, etc.
improved, revived. Nach h-e th’air togail air.
cloth used for drying up when scrubbing. Colloquial, from clobhta, etc.
muffled fall of a person, dead weight fall with a muffled like sound of the trosd family of words. The word, I am afraid, isn’t used now or seldom used. This is one meaning etc.
thread getting ’kinky’. Fhad ’s nach bi e cochladh ort.
a person prone to make a mess.
a showery period in the day.
collecting into a stock, merchandise, ware, etc.
(also) a berry, a black heath berry.
wild savage person. Mar gu canadh tu duin’ air a dhol á [?] fiadh.
bloom, potato bloom. Bàrran [sic] a’ bhuntàta.
a plate from which meat or mutton is served.
shellfish, fishing or trawling for shellfish.
shellfish, fishing or trawling for shellfish.
awkward character or person, relative to confusion in matter of speech, action etc.
speech interruption, a person not easily or readily understood through a way of talking in ‘half measure’.
what is pulled from a tweed material in the form of wool.
gum in which the teeth are held in a person’s mouth.
fast day sermon at a communion festival.
pennyland. The old term way of approaching rent and land system of measurements and tacksmen way of thing as we say.

pennyland. Peighinn-na-h-Aoire – place-name, perhaps comes into this definition of the pennyland system of the tacksmen [see peighinn-fearainn]. The island of Scalpay, Harris, was recognised as coming into the category of a pennyland, etc.
taste. An d’rinn e blasad bithidh idir.
‘haze’ spell, mistake, etc. Dé am buathall a thàinig air?
a term associated with cattle, they attack human beings in an impulse causing them to rouse into a fighting fashion with their heads. Tha ’m bualadh ann. Tha e bualadh. Tha nàdur bualaidh ann.
lasting. ’S iomadh rud is buaine ’na ’n duine.
existence. Seachd bitheanan ann an cat. Cha téid ann am bith.
warts of wool. Plucan air cuibhrige.
between the handles of a hand barrow.
gust of wind; empty garrulous talk as: Cha’n ’eil ann as roc[sic]-gaoithe.
decorative material on clothing, tapes, strips of cloth in a decorative fashion on clothing.
strips, strips of cloth. Stiapan fada.
formation of clouds resembling the stripes or pattern on the mackerel (fish).
piece of cloth over a hole, hinged like for to cover a hole or over a hole, flapping piece of material, a tongue piece of soft flexible material.
the water in which the eggs were boiled.
the water after being used in washing up, scrubbing the floor.
a makeshift beach for a boat.
storm bound in port; in port, for some reason, etc.
whitening. Na pocannan an sud a’ gealadh ris a’ ghréin ’s a muigh fo’n uisge. Cloth material losing colour through neglect in the open, outside.
decaying smell, smell from decaying perishables.
trashing, severe trashing [thrashing?]. Fhuair thu na codachaedells ud (a boy being severely punished).
slashed or skelped, termed [terms?] used in similarity.
puddings from the shop, black puddings etc.
(also) peering or piercing character of female.
on the dot form of expression.
(also) surly looking person (with swollen like cheeks as denoting more of the meaning of the word). Burasach grànnda. It may have originated from buralaich or burralaich (wailing, crying).
wee push. Thoir putag bheag dhi.
small stout female (perhaps not used likewise today).
stir. Dé’n steur a tha’n duin’ ud a’ deanamh.
refuse from the intestines of a dead sheep, etc.
(also) waggle, as: Sgoladh dhe mo theanga.
smearing stool used when smearing sheep.
a Dutch vessel, merchant vessel, etc.
sea boat. ’S e bàta-mara math th’innte. (already noted perhaps)
cha robh mar a bhitheadh ann.
here as noted to me indicates: flawless.
shade, fraction, equally as: Gu’n siomal a dh’athrachadh, etc.
